speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: So I'd like to talk about being cognitively active.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: So you're retired now.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: What did you  used to do?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I was a nurse for 44 years.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Okay.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And presumably that kept you very busy.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: It did.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: It did.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: It wasn't just that.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I had  five children and I helped my husband run a post office.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So I was working a 70 hour  week in those days because I did two nights night duty.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: They were 12 hour shifts separated  and then I worked in the shop.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So for five years I did that.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So that was, you know, and  looked after the children in the house and that.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And do you do any, now that you've retired, do you do any voluntary work or anything else?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah, I've got involved with things around the church with visiting the housebound and  taking them out and things like that.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And I still, and one of my daughters decided to  get me a job as a transport passenger assistant for special needs on the mini buses that go  around needs.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So they were desperate for them and she said, you'd be good at that mum.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So that was, she signed me up cause she was the manager.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So I did that until I was 77.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And I also did the 11 weeks of the stewarding for the ABRSM music exams.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Would you say that keeping busy is important to you?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Well I'm just a busy person.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So it just comes natural to me.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I can't sit really for long.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And have you always been like that?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Do you have a lot of social support?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes I do.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Well even more so now, now that the children have press ganged me into  Facebook and WhatsApp.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Wow.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I mean it's just, it's just full on around the world, you know.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: You're international friends.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And I believe that you are an Airbnb host.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes I do.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So the world comes to me that way.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Excellent.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And you enjoy that.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And then I'm Facebook friends when they go home apparently in China and Brazil and Rome.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Any invitations to visit?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Brazil.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Wow.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And you said you've got grandchildren.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And great grandchildren.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And great grandchildren. Do you think that intergenerational contact is a good thing?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Very important.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Why?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Because you, when you're busy bringing up children you haven't time to see the world

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: through their eyes or even really listen to them because you're too busy and preoccupied.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: But then grandchildren come along and more importantly now great grandchildren and seeing  the world fresh through these new eyes is just, it's quite mind blowing actually.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So I've learned a lot.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: In the old days grandchildren used to learn at their grandparents knee.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: But nowadays it's the grandparents learning at the grandchildren's knees now.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Oh, do you think?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Definitely.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Oh yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And do you think that it also benefits them to spend time with people of different generations,  different ages?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Well, as I said, they don't use age, you see, which is very releasing because, well, it  just is, you know, after my generation, the way I was brought up to be seen and not heard  and to sit in the parlour with all these old people.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And now, well, you're going around flipping parks, you know, the adventure things and  they're saying, come on the slide with us and all this, you know, which I do.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Which I do.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I don't turn anything down.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: That's the secret.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Not turn anything down.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I say yes, yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Good philosophy.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Except drugs.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Try everything once.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Try everything once.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: What's your view on nutrition and kind of, you know, having a so-called healthy diet?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I think the younger generation stress on it too much, far too much.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: When you think that if my generation are living to be 100 and we were brought up with  dripping sandwiches, meat with marbling in, etc, etc, full cream milk, all the rest of  it, why get stressed out?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: You know, just eat everything in moderation and enjoy life for goodness sake.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: I like that philosophy.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: How do you minimise the effects of stress?

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Do you have any, you know, did you have any techniques or if something stressful happens,  is there anything particular that you do?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Gin and tonic or wine.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Okay, yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I've got a very good thing.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: If I'm really cross with somebody and I'd really like to speak my mind to them, I'm  very good at writing letters.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I don't send the letter to them, but I do write it down and get it out of my system  and I keep it in a drawer in case one day I might need to plonk it down in front of  them.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: But it's, you know, it's off, it's out of my head.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And if I need to go to the doctor about anything, I will write down what I want to say to him  because I don't believe they listen to you all the time, especially a woman, if it's  a man doctor.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Well, you know, it's her, they think, oh God, it's her again, you know?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So I think, put this down and smile at him.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: He's got to read it.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: I think you're in your seventies now.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Do you enjoy being in your seventies?

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: What was your favourite period of, you know, in life?

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: If you can, if there's an answer to that.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: No there isn't.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Right.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: You should just enjoy every day as it comes and not get hung up about age.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Because I'm surrounded by 90 year olds now and honestly, they're like nine years old.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: We have the biggest laughs and they do the silliest things and you know, we feel as if  we've been set free from actual age, you know, you're a mother, set an example to the children  or you're a daughter, you know.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: So do you think it makes a difference, kind of moving on from those responsibilities,  kind of times of life?

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: So when you are looking after your children, is that what you mean by you feel a sense  of relief later?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes, because you're not, no one's judging you, except that you're hanging around too long.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: But apart from that, no, it's good.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I mean, I was brought up by a Victorian father who was a bank manager and it was always,  just remember who I am in this town.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: You know, they were somebody in those days.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: You're my children.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And then I went to a convent grammar.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Just remember who you are, girls.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: You're a convent grammar school girl.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: You know, so it didn't leave much to sin, did it?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: It didn't leave much to...

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: It's a pressure to...

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So yeah, there's all these pressures as you're going through life.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So it's nice to be.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: My husband died in his 50s, so I had to reinvent myself, which was scary, very scary after  being a wife and mother all those years.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: But my goodness me.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: I think it was either earlier this year or last year you did something quite big for  a stranger?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Oh, the kidney donation, yes, in February.

text: February this year?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: You donated a kidney to a stranger?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah, a gentleman, I believe.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Yeah.

text: How did you decide to do that or find out about that and then decide?

text: I found out on Facebook.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Okay.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Don't ask me what the heading was, but I'm already, like most people, donated after death,  you know, everything.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I mean, I'm leaving my body to leave medical school as well, which hasn't pleased one of  my daughters, but there you go.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: How can we grieve if you're still hanging around?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: She said, so, so yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So some of them were for it and some of them weren't.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And going through the transplant, the operation, it's quite a big thing to go through.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Well, I think all last year I was doing tests, you know, everything from psychological tests  to all the physical tests and brain scans and everything scanned.

text: It was better than a thousand mile service and I thought, well, I'm doing this for the  right reasons, I know that, but who knows?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: They might find something totally wrong with me and that's the way I found out.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So it's a win-win situation, I believe.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And you know that if they do accept you, and I was the oldest one that they've ever had,  they said, and it'll last 20 years, apparently, a kidney can last 20 years.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: That was good.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So it's a win-win.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: I think I've asked most things on my list that I wanted to talk about.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Is there anything that you think that I've missed that is worth covering in terms of  the theme of living well for longer?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Well, I think if you can do something for somebody else, for whatever reason, however  tiny, the comeback to yourself is just huge.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: But as long as you don't look for that comeback, but it just is.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And it also consolidates the reason why you're still alive, that you're not just taking up  space on the planet, and that you should do something, like in January, hopefully,  tandem parachute jump for Alzheimer's.

text: Oh, is that the plan?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: That's the plan when I'm 80.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Right.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: For Alzheimer's.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Tandem jump out of the plane.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah, yeah.

text: Wow.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Yeah.

text: That's really good.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Is there any advice that you would give to yourself, age 20, or any of our students?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Not to have taken life so seriously.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Right.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Well, one, you don't know how long you're here for.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And two, nobody's that important.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: You know, you're not the centre of the universe, for goodness sake.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So just get on with things.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: It's like, I feel sorry with Facebook, you know, if they don't get enough likes.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: You know, it must ruin the day, some people.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Well, this is all false.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: It's all smoke and murder.

text: One thing a friend did say to me that was very important, and I very proudly was saying  that I now owned my own house, you see.

text: And she just laughed and she said, do you think you'd, really?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I went, yes, you know.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Oh, you're taking it with you, are you?

text: She said, you don't own anything, she said.
